report_title: Pet Grooming and Boarding Industry Report
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Households have increasingly come to consider pets to be an integral part of the family. In recent years, a record-high pet ownership rate boosted spending on pet care services, including grooming and boarding. The pet care sector has flourished as pet owners sought the best for their pets – which materialized in this industry through services like high-end boarding and luxury grooming packages. The pandemic disrupted the industry's growth trajectory: work-from-home arrangements and travel restrictions left more pet owners at home, lowering the need for pet care services and leading revenue to sink for the first time in more than two decades. At the same time, a spike in pet ownership during the pandemic created a shift for the industry that saw demand for pet grooming and boarding ultimately increase to such an extent that it outpaced supply. Pet owners' steep spending on pets has led industry-wide revenue to expand at an estimated CAGR of 6.0% over the last five years, totaling approximately $14.7 billion and including an expected 1.3% increase in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pet Owners Are Willing to Splurge on High-End Pet Care Services
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: According to a 2023 Pew Research Center survey, 97.0% of US households view pets as family members. Pet owners are more willing to shell out on services prioritizing their companions' health and well-being. Millennial pet parents in particular show their willingness to pay top dollar for their pets. Spending behaviors on pets more closely mirror spending on popular consumer trends. Pet owners are spending more on premium pet stays than on traditional boarding.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising per capita disposable income and consumer spending
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising per capita disposable income and consumer spending have supported consumers' approach to pet ownership in recent years. Increases in disposable income have also encouraged consumer spending on travel. For pet owners, trips translate into spending on pet boarding, supporting growth.

The COVID-19 pandemic disrupted growth trends. Work-from-home setups and travel restrictions left pet owners with more time at home to spend with pets, depressing demand for pet boarding. Temporary closures brought substantial financial challenges to pet care service providers. When businesses reopened amid the pandemic, hesitant pet owners deferred pet care like grooming and training sessions because of safety concerns. Grooming services were slightly more resistant to the pandemic's effects since grooming is necessary for some breeds.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pet Owners Scramble to Find Care After the Pandemic Puppy Boom
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During the pandemic, consumers sought out pets as a form of companionship, encouraged by the uptick in available free time. More than 23.0 million households adopted a pet during the pandemic, according to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STRONG DEMAND FOR INDUSTRY SERVICES WILL PERSIST
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Pet owners will continue to be more willing to pay premium prices for top-quality pet care services, while a high pet ownership rate will leave pets needing grooming and boarding care. Inflation, high interest rates and a supply and demand imbalance pushed up the cost of pet care services in the current period. Owners have kept up demand despite the uptick in cost. Some pet services are nondiscretionary, so pet owners will continue paying higher prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE NEED FOR PET CARE WILL GROW AS WORK ARRANGEMENTS EVOLVE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While travel rates will settle from their peaks during the initial pandemic recovery, pet owners will still need boarding and daytime daycare. Many companies are maintaining remote work environments, but more and more are instituting hybrid work arrangements or the resumption of full in-person weeks altogether. This will lead pet owners to prioritize daytime care for their animals, benefiting walkers and daycare providers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: New Entrants Will Up the Level of Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competitive pressures won't subside. Few barriers to entry and little oversight make it relatively easy for new companies to enter the Pet Grooming and Boarding industry. More pet care facilities will offer amenities for animals like pools, playgrounds and games to attract pet owners as competition expands. Technology's role is limited in the pet care space but tech features like webcams and online booking platforms will become expected by discerning pet owners. According to the American Pet Products Association in March 2023, use of pet monitoring systems is increasing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: EXTERNAL COMPETITION WILL INHIBIT STRONGER GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competition from pet retailers, veterinary hospitals and at-home pet care will remain a threat over the next five years. By offering reliable quality and convenient pet care, pet groomers and boarders can retain their customers and attract new ones on the basis of their reputation. Despite the rising external competition, revenue for pet groomers and boarders is still expected to grow throughout 2024, albeit at a slower rate.

industry_definition: The Pet Grooming and Boarding industry provides pet care services, such as boarding, grooming, walking and training. Adoptions, shelter services and end-of-life pet care are also included in this industry.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - increasing

key_trends: Saturated local markets create high competition among both pet boarders and groomers. Pet professionals compete by offering
Low barriers to entry limit concentration
A jump in pet ownership during the COVID-19 pandemic
No pet boarder or groomer has a market share of 5.0% or greater
Pet boarders and groomers have a lax regulatory environment
A return to onsite work for many owners, increased travel and higher rates of pet ownership are all creating strong ongoing demand for industry services.
The shortage of pet professionals has driven up wage growth.
Pet care professionals aren't enjoying higher profit.
High-cost metropolitan areas have the highest levels of pet spending.
A shift in attitudes toward pets has led pet-related spending to escalate.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Millennials – adults aged 27 to 42 – have adopted a new approach to pet ownership when compared with their older cohorts. This demographic views pets as a part of the family and has adjusted spending behaviors to reflect this. Millennial pet owners will become the largest and most influential market in the industry as this age cohort gets older and purchasing power expands.

Generation X-ers, adults aged 42 to 59, are the industry's largest market despite having a slightly lower pet ownership rate than millennials. Gen X pet owners have more money to spend on their pets, especially when compared with younger generations like millennials and Gen Z. Higher spending offsets their lower pet ownership rate.

Baby boomers, ages 59 to 77, constitute an important market for pet groomers and boarders – especially since their pet ownership levels are comparable to millennials'. These pet owners are substantial drivers of pet spending overall but are less willing to pay for premium pet care, opting instead for more basic service levels.

products_and_services.product_description: Pet grooming includes cutting and shaving fur; trimming nails; and cleaning fur, ears and teeth to improve pets' appearance and hygiene. Other grooming services include massages, flea and tick removal and baths, deshedding baths and undercoat removal.
Pet boarding, including overnight and daytime care, refers to a pet care facility or business that houses and cares for an animal (most commonly dogs) in its owner's absence.

Pet training covers general obedience classes for puppies and dogs, group classes, guide dog training and private lessons. An influx of new pet adoptions during the pandemic translated to a higher need for dog trainers.
Other pet care services include walking, end-of-life pet care, race animal training, adoptions and shelter services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Trends in pet ownership influence demand for grooming and boarding.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: When more people become pet owners, the need for grooming and boarding services increases since consumers require these services to supplement their own care for their pets.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the nation's population resides in the Southeast region. Since the distribution of pet groomers and boarders mostly follows population trends, this region comprises nearly one-quarter of the industry. Within the region, Florida has the highest number of pet care providers. Florida's large population warrants more groomers and boarders to meet high levels of demand.

The West's large population also elicits many pet care providers. A high population provides groomers and boarders access to more pet owners than in less populated areas. California is responsible for the region's share of pet care companies. The state has the most pet care providers in the US and the region. According to the US Census Bureau, California has one of the highest median incomes per household in the United States. A high household income increases spending on higher-margin grooming and boarding services.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Animal Welfare Act (AWA) impacts the pet grooming and boarding industry by setting strict standards for animal care and treatment. Regulations cover housing facilities, food supply and storage, cleaning protocols, waste disposal, access to water, exercise requirements, and safety procedures.

Several states, including New Jersey and New York, have introduced legislation to directly regulate groomers. They would require dog groomers to obtain a license and in New Jersey, applicants must pass an examination. It wasn't passed, but has been in discussion for a decade.

basis_points.basis_title: Saturated local markets create high competition
basis_points.basis_description: Saturated local markets create high competition among both pet boarders and groomers. Pet professionals compete by offering auxiliary services.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low Barriers to Entry Equal High Concentration and Heightened Competition
concentration_points.concentration_description: Few obstacles exist that prevent a new boarding or grooming company from opening. New competitors can join the industry freely without substantial

Many pet grooming and boarding establishments thrive on localized knowledge and expertise. They cater specifically to the needs, preferences and tastes of their local communities, creating high customer loyalty.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Pet care providers need knowledgeable and trained employees to care for animals. Grooming facilities have higher labor requirements because of their specialized nature and potential safety risks.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumer Spending Determines How Pet Owners Use Pet Care
volatility_points.volatility_description: Pet owners use dog walkers and pet boarders when they are at work or are otherwise away from their pets. With more time at home, demand for pet care plummeted during the pandemic. Consumers' pent-up demand for travel and a return to on-site work reversed this trend, benefiting the industry but adding to volatility relative to travel and employment patterns.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Pet Care Services Are a Mainstay in Pet Owners' Lives
volatility_points.volatility_description: Busy pet owners rely on pet care services like grooming, walking and boarding to supplement their care for their pets. Pet owners outsource these services when they don't have the skills or time to perform them independently. Dependence on pet professionals limits volatility in the industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Pet Owners Pay Up for Convenience
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Mobile dog groomers existed prior to the pandemic but their popularity soared out of necessity during lockdowns and business closures. This trend has continued, as mobile grooming services offer convenience and peace of mind for which pet owners are willing to pay a premium.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales reliant on the overall health of the US economy (i.e. consumer spending and per capita disposable income)?
FAQs.answer: The pet grooming and boarding industry is relatively protected from the effects of a recession. That being said, rising unemployment and individuals

FAQs.question: How does lower consumer spending amid economic downturns impact your business?
What is the National Dog Groomers Association of America?
FAQs.answer: The National Dog Groomers Association of America (NDGAA) is a professional membership association representing those engaged in the grooming and care of dogs. NDGAA works to upgrade the profession of pet grooming through encouraging professionalism, networking and promoting high grooming standards. The association offers membership programs, educational workshops, competitions and seminars.

FAQs.question: How do some industry companies form partnerships?
FAQs.answer: Some industry companies form partnerships with pet stores to combine their markets.

FAQs.question: When does demand for pet boarding increase?
FAQs.answer: Demand for pet boarding increases during times of heavy travel, like during the holidays.

FAQs.question: What is a key challenge for companies in managing costs?
FAQs.answer: Companies must find a way to manage costs without cutting quality standards.

FAQs.question: How do many small operators in this industry market themselves?
FAQs.answer: Many operators in this industry are small and have limited marketing budgets. How does your company leverage social media platforms, such as Facebook,

FAQs.question: What mobile platforms do many pet sitters use?
FAQs.answer: Many pet sitters use mobile platforms like Wag, Rover and Trusted House Sitters.

FAQs.question: Have you considered investing in a mobile app?
FAQs.answer: Many businesses are launching their own mobile apps as more consumers are using smart devices. Industry operators could benefit from having an app that allows consumers to book and pay for services.

FAQs.question: Is your company subject to any franchising laws?
FAQs.answer: Many larger companies sell franchise rights. Depending on their location, they may be subject to strict franchising laws that can increase the cost of expanding.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Companies must heavily vet pet sitters and groomers because people are protective of their pets.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Companies must maintain quality standards to ensure pets are kept safe.

FAQs.question: As many people are spending more time at home, some pet owners have had a decreased need for industry services. What impact does this have on your revenue and profitability?
FAQs.answer: Many pet groomers have faced lower demand as owners are taking on more responsibilities related to the care of their pets. This causes the industry's profit to decline.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain a high quality of customer service? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: High quality grooming and other pet care services ensure repeat visits by customers and word-of-mouth recommendations. Consumers often treat their animals likely members of their family and are therefore very protective over them.

FAQs.question: Do you track the number of households? Are you located in a densely populated area?
FAQs.answer: Pet ownership and demand for industry services tend to coincide with household formation. It is important that operators are strategically located in areas with growing populations.

FAQs.question: Do you have enough resources to handle the wave of new pet owners? How do you plan to cater to new pet owners?
FAQs.answer: Pet ownership has been on the rise, which is one of the main reasons for this industry's growth.
